content.description: OK climbing on mostly big & plentiful holds.  There is a bit of loose rock on top so be careful.
content.protection: Bolts & a bolted anchor.  Rappel the route to descend.
content.location: Located on the east side of Queen Scepter.  Scramble up to the highest point on the east side to a pair of belay bolts.  Follow 4 bolts up the face to a 2 bolt anchor.

climbs.name: Queen Scepter
climbs.fa: Jim Steagall, Ken Mills, & Eric Hanson

content.description:
A nice line up the west face through several roofs & bulges.  Start up easier climbing to the first (crux) roof.  A couple hard moves gets you to jugs, which continue to the top.   

  Although the technical crux is short, the overhanging nature of the climb makes for a pumpy route all the way to the top.
content.protection: Many bolts (maybe 15?) get you to a bolted anchor.  While this route is generally very well protected, the first bolt is a bit high, albeit on easier climbing.  An intermittent crack near the bottom lets one tame the initial runout with a medium-ish nut.
content.location: Climb is located on the west face of Queen Scepter.  There are 2 bolted lines on the west face; Queen Scepter is the right (south) one.

content.description: Climbs up an easier face to the crux roof.  Tackle the roof and enjoy the headwall.
content.location: The obvious pillar on the right side of the road before the Pond.

content.description: A decent route with a harder-than-it-looks-from-the-ground crux.  Don't cheat by stemming out onto the ramp on the right.
content.protection: Lots of bolts and a 2 bolt anchor.  Rap the route to descend.
content.location: Climb starts on the south side of Queen Scepter.  Follow bolts up the face to crux bulge on the southeast arete, then thin, lower angle climbing to the anchor.  Try not to cheat by stepping out onto the ramp that leads to Whistling Idiot.

content.description: A nice tower with several roofs & bulges and 4 sport routes.
